1:30 is where we finds the equation for normal force.  So when we are moving with a CONSTANT acceleration in any direction, the weighing scale remains the same. When we are we are moving with a NON-CONSTANT acceleration, the weighing scale becomes larger going up, smaller going down.
It depends on if the acceleration is constant or not. If constant, the is no change to the scale If non-constant, the scale reads less

Suppose if a 2kg body experiences a acceleration of 12 m/s^2 in the downward direction.  Then Fnet = (ay+g)*m                    =(-12m/s^2 + 9.8 m/s^2) * 2 kg = -4.4N  So, what does it mean? Negative net force in an elevator?

When you're standing still on a scale, you are undergoing a state of static equilibrium, meaning that v = 0 and Fnet = 0. Both Fn (normal force, aka the force "being applied by the scale itself") and Fg (weight) have the same magnitude but act in opposite directions. So you are correct that the scale measures Fn, but the magnitude of Fn is the same as Fg in this scenario! It is a perfect example of Newton's 3rd law. Hope this reply wasn't too late haha.

Because then, you are going toward the gravity and as you know when two body goes in the same direction we subtract the speed, velocity & acceleration. that's why he subtracted.

He did include the negative sign but it’s not directly visible to you.  When he applied Newton’s second law, to derive the Fn formula that he’s using throughout the video, he took into consideration the negative sign of mg (the weight) which is in the negative y direction! (Fn - mg = m*a) But you don’t see it bc he added (mg) to both sides of the equation!

Hey I know I'm a year late but try to imagine this situation like this :   If you are in an elevator and the elevator goes on accelerating in the upward direction  you would feel that you are getting  glued to the floor of the elevator as it's acceleration increases for example in a roller coaster due to sudden change in acceleration you fallback and get glued to your seat  hence your apparent weight would be w = m(g+ay) also the fN would be the same as w goes on increasing fN also goes on increasing  equally so as to balance each other . Hope this helps 😊
